newsitem.title: TURKEY: Turkish generals serve notice on Islamist premier.
newsitem.headline: Turkish generals serve notice on Islamist premier.

text.p: Turkey's generals have warned the ruling Islamists that they want a government crackdown on what they see as a wave of religious zeal threatening secular democracy.

The army brass used a nine-hour meeting of the National Security Council to demand Necmettin Erbakan, modern Turkey's first Islamist prime minister, get tough with the very religious radicals who make up a key portion of his constituency.

Turkish newspapers said on Sunday the military-dominated Council, guardian of the secular system and a vestige from an earlier era of army rule, presented in the meeting on Friday a detailed list of measures designed to rein in religious ferment.
But Erbakan sought to paper over the rift, telling his Welfare Party leadership the army and the politicians "were in complete harmony".

The liberal daily Radikal said the army's demands included tighter supervision of religious instruction, surveillance and even closing of the often-secretive Islamic brotherhoods, or tarikats, and enforcement of restrictions on Islamic dress.

Other steps include limiting enrolment in religious training programmes, investigations of Islamist-owned businesses -- a key source of Welfare's funding -- and cutting off grants to Turkish students abroad who engage in Islamist activities.
"The country's NSC is recommending the country's government take precautions against itself," said Radikal commentator Ismet Berkan.
The NSC said it would create a system to monitor progress on its wish-list under the direction of General Ilhan Kilic, the council's general secretary, Radikal said.
The burden of enforcing the measures will fall largely on Erbakan's justice minister, a provincial lawyer already under assault for catering to Islamic militancy, the paper said.
NSC meetings are closed to the press and participants made no comment beyond a joint communique issued after the meeting. Other newspapers carried lists similar to that in Radikal.

Erbakan's Islamist backers and his secularist coalition partner, Foreign Minister Tansu Ciller, were keen to play down the rift, declaring that the army would not mount a coup. But all politicians, and virtually any Turkish schoolchild, can reel off the three previous occasions when the army stepped into domestic politics.
"The coup dossier has been closed," said the Islamist daily Yeni Safak in a frontpage headline.
"Let no one have any expectation that democracy will be interrupted," Ciller told reporters on Saturday.

Erbakan, meanwhile, told leaders of his Welfare Party in Ankara he would be meeting other parliamentary factions later this week "to expand further the atmosphere of tranquillity and security in the country".
However, there were few indications the top force commanders, none of whom made any comment after the marathon NSC meeting, were prepared to sit on their hands forever.

The army has intervened three times before when it felt events were spinning out of control. The most recent intervention, in 1980, followed years of left-right street violence but was ostensibly sparked by a pro-Islamist rally Erbakan led in the Anatolian city of Konya.
Friday's meeting capped months of escalating tensions over the increasingly Islamist policies of the coalition government and Turkey's secularist elite, bolstered by the armed forces.
Last month General Cevik Bir, the armed forces' second-in-command, used a visit to the United States to blast the Islamists and to vow not to permit any change in NATO-member Turkey's secular order.
And on February 4, army commanders sent a tank column on manoeuvres through an Islamist district of Ankara after an anti-Israel protest gave way to demands for the introduction of Koranic sharia law.
